nodes.text: The Almost Ideal Demand System (AIDS) provides a flexible, theoretically consistent, and practically estimable demand system that is preferable to existing models for testing and extending conventional demand analysis
AIDS is derived from a PIGLOG class cost function log c(u,p) = (1-u) log a(p) + u log b(p) with specific flexible parametric forms for log a(p) and log b(p)
AIDS budget share equations are linear in parameters: wi = ai + sum_j yij log pj + beta_i log(x/P), where P is a price index

AIDS satisfies key theoretical properties: exact satisfaction of choice axioms, linear homogeneity in prices, adding-up, homogeneity and Slutsky symmetry can be imposed as linear restrictions, and it aggregates exactly over consumers under PIGLOG assumptions

AIDS is a first-order flexible functional form equivalent in generality to translog and Rotterdam models but has advantages including exact axiomatic satisfaction and straightforward linear testing of homogeneity and symmetry
Derivation uses Shephard's lemma: price derivatives of the cost function give demands, and logarithmic differentiation of the chosen cost function produces the budget share form

Parameter restrictions: adding-up requires sum_i ai =1, homogeneity requires sum_j yij =0 for each i, and symmetry requires yij = yji; negativity (concavity) must be checked via eigenvalues of the Slutsky matrix

AIDS relates to other models: first differences yield a form close to Rotterdam; indirect translog is a special PIGLOG case under extra restrictions; parameters have different interpretations across models

Aggregation result: under household-level PIGLOG (or PIGL) demand functions with household scale factors kh, aggregate budget shares correspond to a representative consumer with representative budget x/k

Estimation strategy: approximate price index P by Stone index P* = exp(sum Wk log pk) to linearize equations and estimate by OLS equation-by-equation; then iterate using P from symmetric estimates to reestimate full system
Limitation: large number of parameters risks weak identification and collinearity; a0 (scale parameter) may be hard to identify and concavity is not guaranteed by linear restrictions alone
Interpretation: ai and bi correspond to subsistence and bliss shares; yij measure (approximate) compensated cross-price effects and beta_i classify luxuries (positive) and necessities (negative)

Empirical application on UK annual data 1954-1974 for eight nondurable groups: estimated AIDS explains much variance but tests reject homogeneity and symmetry in levels; homogeneity imposition induces positive serial correlation in some residuals

Empirical results detail: many yij coefficients significantly different from zero; expenditure elasticities indicate food and housing as necessities and several goods as luxuries; overall price inelasticity except transport

First-difference estimation reduces some rejections of homogeneity and makes some intercepts significant, suggesting omitted variables, trends, stock effects, price expectations, or intertemporal structure may explain violations of static model assumptions

Overall conclusion: AIDS is recommended as a simple, general, theory-consistent platform for demand analysis and for extending models to include dynamics, stock effects, expectations, or demographic distribution effects, but further work is needed to enforce concavity and to model omitted variables
